questions: You review a 62-year-old man three days after he had been admitted with an acute coronary syndrome. His past medical history includes myasthenia gravis for which he takes long-term prednisolone. Since admission his symptoms of myasthenia have become markedly worse. In particular you notice bilateral ptosis and slurring of speech. Which of the following recently started medications is most likely to be responsible?
notes: Beta-blockers such as bisoprolol are common precipitants of myasthenic crises.
question: You review a 62-year-old man three days after he had been admitted with an acute coronary syndrome. His past medical history includes myasthenia gravis for which he takes long-term prednisolone. Since admission his symptoms of myasthenia have become markedly worse. In particular you notice bilateral ptosis and slurring of speech. Which of the following recently started medications is most likely to be responsible?
question_notes: Beta-blockers such as bisoprolol are common precipitants of myasthenic crises.
title: Myasthenia gravis: exacerbating factors
body:
The most common exacerbating factor is exertion resulting in fatigability, which is the hallmark feature of myasthenia gravis.. Symptoms become more marked during the day

The following drugs may exacerbate myasthenia:
  • penicillamine
  • quinidine, procainamide
  • beta-blockers
  • lithium
  • phenytoin
  • antibiotics: gentamicin, macrolides, quinolones, tetracyclines
links:
Royal College of Physicians (Edin)66
Myasthenia gravis review


Myasthenia Gravis Association75
Drugs which may aggravate myasthenia gravis

Myasthenia gravis - causes, symptoms, treatment, pathology

Myasthenia gravis
Zero to Finals - YouTube01

questions:
A 23-year-old man is brought into the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. He is given metoclopramide by an F1, however 20 minutes later he complains that his eyes are trapped in a strange position, and he is unable to move them.

What has happened to this man?
notes: Metoclopramide can cause extrapyramidal side effects, most commonly acute dystonia causing oculogyric crises, as is described in the history above. Young people are at particular risk of this. Akathisia is a sense of motor restlessness and is a long term side effect, parkinsonism would be changes in gait and resting tremor, and tardive dyskinesia would be abnormal involuntary movements like licking lips. This is not a typical history of an allergic reaction- there is no swelling of face or lips and no breathing or circulatory problems, and no rash mentioned.
question:
A 23-year-old man is brought into the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. He is given metoclopramide by an F1, however 20 minutes later he complains that his eyes are trapped in a strange position, and he is unable to move them.

What has happened to this man?
question_notes: Metoclopramide can cause extrapyramidal side effects, most commonly acute dystonia causing oculogyric crises, as is described in the history above. Young people are at particular risk of this. Akathisia is a sense of motor restlessness and is a long term side effect, parkinsonism would be changes in gait and resting tremor, and tardive dyskinesia would be abnormal involuntary movements like licking lips. This is not a typical history of an allergic reaction- there is no swelling of face or lips and no breathing or circulatory problems, and no rash mentioned.
title: Metoclopramide
body:
Metoclopramide is a D2 receptor antagonist* mainly used in the management of nausea. Other uses include:
  • gastro-oesophageal reflux disease
  • prokinetic action is useful in gastroparesis secondary to diabetic neuropathy
  • often combined with analgesics for the treatment of migraine (migraine attacks result in gastroparesis, slowing the absorption of analgesics)

Adverse effects
  • extrapyramidal effects
    • acute dystonia e.g. oculogyric crisis
    • this is particularly a problem in children and young adults
  • diarrhoea
  • hyperprolactinaemia
  • tardive dyskinesia
  • parkinsonism

Metoclopramide should be avoided in bowel obstruction, but may be helpful in paralytic ileus.


*whilst metoclopramide is primarily a D2 receptor antagonist, the mechanism of action is quite complicated:
  • it is also a mixed 5-HT3 receptor antagonist/5-HT4 receptor agonist
  • the antiemetic action is due to its antagonist activity at D2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone. At higher doses the 5-HT3 receptor antagonist also has an effect
  • the gastroprokinetic activity is mediated by D2 receptor antagonist activity and 5-HT4 receptor agonist activity
concept: Metoclopramide can cause extrapyramidal side effects, the earliest of which is mainly acute dystonia
links:
BNF79
Metoclopramide
media:
Pharmacology - Antiemetics
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube100

1878.concept_text: Metoclopramide can cause drug-induced hyperprolactinaemia presenting as hypogonadism in men

2591.concept_text: Metoclopramide works through antagonism of the D2 dopamine receptors

4099.concept_text: Metoclopramide can cause extrapyramidal side effects, the earliest of which is mainly acute dystonia

5671.concept_text: Oculogyric crisis is an adverse effect of metoclopramide use in children and young adults

options: Cystic fibrosis is due to a defect in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
Cystic fibrosis is an X-linked recessive disease
Cystic fibrosis is caused by trisomy 21
Cystic fibrosis is not detected on the neonatal heel prick test
questions:
You are GPST1 in GP practice. Laura is a 26-year-old lady who attends your clinic and would like some information on cystic fibrosis. She has previously been told she is a carrier.

Which one of the following is correct?
notes:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder causing increased viscosity of secretions (e.g. lungs and pancreas). It is due to a defect in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR), which codes a cAMP-regulated chloride channel

In the UK 80% of CF cases are due to delta F508 on the long arm of chromosome 7. Cystic fibrosis affects 1 per 2500 births, and the carrier rate is c. 1 in 25.
question:
You are GPST1 in GP practice. Laura is a 26-year-old lady who attends your clinic and would like some information on cystic fibrosis. She has previously been told she is a carrier.

Which one of the following is correct?
question_notes:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder causing increased viscosity of secretions (e.g. lungs and pancreas). It is due to a defect in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR), which codes a cAMP-regulated chloride channel

In the UK 80% of CF cases are due to delta F508 on the long arm of chromosome 7. Cystic fibrosis affects 1 per 2500 births, and the carrier rate is c. 1 in 25.
title: Cystic fibrosis
body:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder causing increased viscosity of secretions (e.g. lungs and pancreas). It is due to a defect in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR), which codes a cAMP-regulated chloride channel

In the UK 80% of CF cases are due to delta F508 on the long arm of chromosome 7. Cystic fibrosis affects 1 per 2500 births, and the carrier rate is c. 1 in 25

Organisms which may colonise CF patients
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Burkholderia cepacia*
  • Aspergillus

*previously known as Pseudomonas cepacia
concept: Cystic fibrosis is due to a defect in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)

questions:
A 66-year-old woman presents to her GP with a 2-day history of urinary frequency and dysuria. She has a urine dip which is positive for blood, leucocytes, nitrites, and protein. She has a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis for which she takes methotrexate and hypertension for which she takes ramipril. She has no allergies. The patient is anxious because she has been warned about an antibiotic which she should avoid due to her current medications.

Which medication out of those listed has she been warned about?
notes:
This patient should not be given trimethoprim concurrently with methotrexate due to the risk of bone marrow aplasia. As methotrexate and trimethoprim are both anti-folate medications, the additive folate depletion when combined can lead to pancytopenia, megaloblastic anaemia, and bone marrow suppression.

Cefalexin is not known to cause anti-folate effects and can be administered to patients alongside methotrexate. It is a first-generation cephalosporin that is used in the management of genital, urinary, and respiratory infections.

Ciclosporin is not an antibiotic and is not indicated in the management of urinary tract infections. It is used in the management of severe ulcerative colitis refractive to steroids and severe rheumatoid arthritis. It is not an anti-folate medication and is not associated with bone marrow suppression. It can be given alongside methotrexate.

Doxycycline is an antibiotic used in the management of Chlamydia trachomatis and certain severe, urinary tract infections where the urine culture has been performed. It is not associated with bone marrow suppression when given alongside methotrexate.

Nitrofurantoin is not associated with bone marrow suppression and does not need to be avoided in patients taking methotrexate.

Penicillins (e.g. amoxicillin & co-amoxiclav) may reduce the excretion of methotrexate.

As methotrexate and trimethoprim are both anti-folate medications, the additive folate depletion when combined can lead to pancytopenia, megaloblastic anaemia, and bone marrow suppression.

Cefalexin is not known to cause anti-folate effects and can be administered to patients alongside methotrexate. It is a first-generation cephalosporin that is used in the management of genital, urinary, and respiratory infections.

Ciclosporin is not an antibiotic and is not indicated in the management of urinary tract infections. It is used in the management of severe ulcerative colitis refractive to steroids and severe rheumatoid arthritis. It is not an anti-folate medication and is not associated with bone marrow suppression. It can be given alongside methotrexate.

Doxycycline is an antibiotic used in the management of Chlamydia trachomatis and certain severe, urinary tract infections where the urine culture has been performed. It is not associated with bone marrow suppression when given alongside methotrexate.

Nitrofurantoin is not associated with bone marrow suppression and does not need to be avoided in patients taking methotrexate.

Penicillins (e.g. amoxicillin & co-amoxiclav) may reduce the excretion of methotrexate.
title: Trimethoprim
body:
Trimethoprim is an antibiotic, mainly used in the management of urinary tract infections.

Mechanism of action
  • interferes with DNA synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase
    • may, therefore, interact with methotrexate, which also inhibits dihydrofolate reductase

Adverse effects
  • myelosuppression
  • rise in creatinine
    • trimethoprim inhibits tubular secretion of creatinine in the proximal tubule.
    • this is a pharmacological effect on renal handling of creatinine, not true renal injury.
    • because creatinine clearance is reduced (without GFR actually falling), the serum creatinine rises
    • the rise in creatinine is typically 10–30% above baseline and occurs rapidly after starting trimethoprim
    • it does not reflect a genuine decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
    • trimethoprim blocks the ENaC channel in the distal nephron, causing a hyperkalaemic distal RTA (type 4)

Use in pregnancy
  • the BNF advises that there is a: 'Teratogenic risk in first trimester (folate antagonist). Manufacturers advise avoid during pregnancy.'
concept: Trimethoprim and co-trimoxazole should be avoided in patients on methotrexate

3132.concept_text: Trimethoprim and co-trimoxazole should be avoided in patients on methotrexate

questions:
A 24-year-old man is seen in gastroenterology clinic with severe ulcerative colitis. It is recommended that he should commence azathioprine to improve his symptoms.

What should be ruled out prior to starting this medication?
notes:
Thiopurine methyltransferase is the enzyme required to metabolism azathioprine, a small proportion of the population had reduced activity or deficiency of this enzyme putting them at risk of azathioprine toxicity. Accordingly. levels should be tested prior to commencing the drug with cautious dosing or an alternate therapy used if TPMT is found.

DPD deficiency means the body is unable to break down thiamine and uracil, in such cases, 5-fluorouracil should be avoided where possible, or used with extreme caution to avoid toxicity.

Folate deficiency is associated with methotrexate use. Folate levels are not affected by azathioprine and do not require checking prior to treatment.

Gal-1-put is deficient in galactosaemia, people with this condition should avoid galactose.

G6PD deficiency puts patients at risk of haemolytic crises in response to a number of triggers, including various medications including antimalarials and some anti-biotics. Azathioprine is not a common trigger for haemolysis in G6PD deficiency.

A 24-year-old man is seen in gastroenterology clinic with severe ulcerative colitis. It is recommended that he should commence azathioprine to improve his symptoms.

question_notes:

Accordingly. levels should be tested prior to commencing the drug with cautious dosing or an alternate therapy used if TPMT is found.

Folate deficiency is associated with methotrexate use. Folate levels are not affected by azathioprine and do not require checking prior to treatment.

Gal-1-put is deficient in galactosaemia, people with this condition should avoid galactose.

G6PD deficiency puts patients at risk of haemolytic crises in response to a number of triggers, including various medications including antimalarials and some anti-biotics. Azathioprine is not a common trigger for haemolysis in G6PD deficiency.
title: Azathioprine
body:
Azathioprine is metabolised to the active compound mercaptopurine, a purine analogue that inhibits purine synthesis. A thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT) test may be needed to look for individuals prone to azathioprine toxicity.

Adverse effects include
  • bone marrow depression
    • consider a full blood count if infection/bleeding occurs
  • nausea/vomiting
  • pancreatitis
  • increased risk of non-melanoma skin cancer

A significant interaction may occur with allopurinol and hence lower doses of azathioprine should be used.

Azathioprine is generally considered safe to use in pregnancy.
  • data show no increased risk of congenital malformations at standard doses.
  • it is considered safer than many alternatives (e.g. mycophenolate, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide - all contraindicated in pregnancy).
  • uncontrolled SLE in pregnancy is a greater risk to both mother and foetus than azathioprine therapy.
concept: Azathioprine - check thiopurine methyltransferase deficiency (TPMT) before treatment
media:
Azathioprine - Pharmacology, mechanism of action, side effects
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube31

820.concept_text: Azathioprine - check thiopurine methyltransferase deficiency (TPMT) before treatment

2628.concept_text: Pancreatitis is an adverse effect of azathioprine

7991.concept_text: Azathioprine may cause myelosuppression - consider a full blood count if infection/bleeding occurs

7992.concept_text: Azathioprine is metabolised to the active compound mercaptopurine, a purine analogue that inhibits purine synthesis

10600.concept_text: Azathioprine is safe to use in pregnancy

questions:
A 6-year-old boy is brought into the emergency department by his mother with an erection that is non-painful and is not completely rigid. The child reports that he noticed it after morning recreation at school but didn't say anything. His mother noticed the erection when helping him get ready for his evening judo class. The child has no past medical or surgical history and takes no regular medications.

What is the most appropriate first-line investigation given this child's presentation?
notes:
This patient is presenting with priapism - he has a partially erect, non-painful penis which remains for over 4 hours. This presentation is likely to be non-ischaemic as the erection is not painful and is not completely erect. Non-ischaemic priapism occurs due to large volume arterial inflow to the penis from trauma or congenital malformation. An important first step is to confirm if the priapism is cavernosal blood gas analysis which will indicate if it is ischaemic or non-ischaemic. This will aid management as ischaemic priapism is a medical emergency warranting aspiration of blood from the cavernosa, whereas non-ischaemic priapism can be managed with observation initially. In Paediatric patients, a doppler ultrasound is an alternative option to consider (if there are radiologists who are able to perform this scan) due to the potentially traumatic nature to a child of cavernosal blood gases.

A CT pelvis would not be useful or recommended in this instance. It would be inappropriate to irradiate the pelvis and genital area of a child when there are alternative imaging modalities more appropriate for investigation of priapism (such as doppler ultrasound to consider the arterial/venous blood flow in the penis).

A clotting screen may be useful if the patient is suspected to have haemoglobinopathy as it may give a more accurate platelet count than a full blood count. However, this patient has no history of any bleeding problems or family history of haemoglobinopathies referred to. This could be a potential further investigation once ischaemic or non-ischaemic priapism has been confirmed, however, it should not delay cavernosal blood gas analysis due to the risk of penile ischaemia.

A testicular ultrasound is not a useful imaging modality to investigate priapism. If an imaging modality were to be used to assess for penile blood flow (often a useful alternative to cavernosal blood gas analysis in Paediatric patients), a doppler ultrasound would be used.

Urea and electrolytes are useful to assess renal function and can indicate if there is a urological issue. However, deranged urea and electrolytes are unlikely to cause priapism. If the child had presented with urological symptoms, blood in the urine, or blood from the penis - this would be a first-line investigation option.

What is the most appropriate first-line investigation given this child's presentation?

title: Priapism
body:
Priapism is a persistent penile erection, typically defined as lasting longer than 4 hours and is not associated with sexual stimulation. Priapism can be described as either ischaemic or non-ischaemic with both categories having a different pathophysiology. Ischaemic priapism is typically due to impaired vasorelaxation and therefore reduced vascular outflow resulting in congestion and trapping of de-oxygenated blood within the corpus cavernosa. Non-ischaemic priapism is due to high arterial inflow, typically due to fistula formation often either as the result of congenital or traumatic mechanisms.

Epidemiology
  • Age at presentation has a bimodal distribution, with peaks between 5-10 years and 20-50 years of age
  • incidence has been estimated at up to 5.34 per 100,000 patient-years

Causes
  • Idiopathic
  • Sickle cell disease or other haemoglobinopathies
  • Erectile dysfunction medication (e.g. Sildenafil and other PDE-5 inhibitors), this also includes intracavernosal injected therapies.
  • Other drugs both prescribed (anti-hypertensives, anticoagulants, antidepressants etc) and recreational (specifically cocaine, cannabis and ecstasy).
  • Trauma

Patients typically present acutely with:
  • A persistent erection lasting over 4 hours
  • Pain localised to the penis
  • Often a history of either known haemoglobinopathy or use of medications listed above
  • Patients may, more rarely, present with either a non-painful erection or an erection that is not fully rigid: these are both suggestive of non-ischaemic priapism.
  • History of trauma to the genital or perineal region: also suggestive of non-ischaemic priapism.


Investigations:
  • Cavernosal blood gas analysis to differentiate between ischaemic and non-ischaemic: in ischaemic priapism pO2 and pH would be reduced whilst pCO2 would be increased.
  • Doppler or duplex ultrasonography: this can be used as an alternative to blood gas analysis to assess for blood flow within the penis.
  • A full blood count and toxicology screen can be used to assess for an underlying cause of the priapism.
  • Diagnosis of priapism is largely clinical, with investigations helping to categorise into ischaemic and non-ischaemic as well as assessing for the underlying cause.

Management

Ischaemic priapism is a medical emergency and delayed treatment can lead to permanent tissue damage and long-term erectile dysfunction.
  • If the priapism has lasted longer than 4 hours, the first-line treatment is aspiration of blood from the cavernosa, this is often combined with injection of a saline flush to help clear viscous blood that has pooled.
  • If aspiration and injection fails, then intracavernosal injection of a vasoconstrictive agent such as phenylephrine is used and repeated at 5 minute intervals.
  • If medical therapy fails then surgical options can be considered.

Non-ischaemic priapism is not a medical emergency and is normally suitable for observation as a first-line option.
concept: Cavernosal blood gas analysis is a useful investigation for priapism

9680.concept_text: Cavernosal blood gas analysis is a useful investigation for priapism

questions:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 6-day history of fever and lethargy. There is no past medical history of note and he is up to date with his childhood vaccinations.

On examination, he is drowsy. His temperature is 39.1ºC, with a heart rate of 150 beats/min and a respiratory rate of 45 breaths/min. There is a maculopapular rash across his torso and upper limbs and his lips are erythematous and cracked. His conjunctivae are inflamed. Kernig's sign is negative.

Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate management?
notes:
Aspirin is correct. This patient has a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease given the combination of persistent fever, conjunctivitis, maculopapular rash and cracked and erythematous lips in a child. The disease is vasculitic in nature and current guidelines recommended initial treatment is high-dose aspirin therapy.

Intravenous aciclovir is incorrect. This would be indicated for viral presentations, such as viral meningitis or encephalitis, but is not used in the management of Kawasaki disease.

Intravenous ceftriaxone is incorrect. This is used for significant bacterial infections such as Neisseria meningitidis. However, it is not used in the treatment of Kawasaki disease. The negative Kernig's sign makes meningitis less likely.

Oral phenoxymethylpenicillin is incorrect. Although the presentation is somewhat similar to scarlet fever (which is treated with oral phenoxymethylpenicillin), the mucosal changes and conjunctivitis are more indicative of Kawasaki disease.

Paracetamol and rehydration therapy is incorrect. Supportive management is recommended for most viral infections, including the more significant viral infections (eg measles). However, a child with a persistent fever beyond 5 days should raise suspicion of a more severe diagnosis, such as Kawasaki disease.

Paracetamol and rehydration therapy is incorrect. Supportive management is recommended for most viral infections, including the more significant viral infections (eg measles). However, a child with a persistent fever beyond 5 days should raise suspicion of a more severe diagnosis, such as Kawasaki disease.
title: Kawasaki disease
body:
Kawasaki disease is a type of vasculitis which is predominately seen in children. Whilst Kawasaki disease is uncommon it is important to recognise as it may cause potentially serious complications, including coronary artery aneurysms.

Features
  • high-grade fever which lasts for > 5 days. Fever is characteristically resistant to antipyretics
  • conjunctival injection
  • bright red, cracked lips
  • strawberry tongue
  • cervical lymphadenopathy
  • red palms of the hands and the soles of the feet which later peel

Kawasaki disease is a clinical diagnosis as there is no specific diagnostic test.

Management
  • high-dose aspirin
    • Kawasaki disease is one of the few indications for the use of aspirin in children. Due to the risk of Reye's syndrome aspirin is normally contraindicated in children
  • intravenous immunoglobulin
  • echocardiogram (rather than angiography) is used as the initial screening test for coronary artery aneurysms

Complications
  • coronary artery aneurysm
concept: High dose aspirin is indicated in Kawasaki disease, despite it usually being contraindicated in children
media:
Kawasaki disease
Khan Academy - YouTube10
 
Kawasaki disease
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube221
 
Kawasaki disease
Osmosis - YouTube112

2892.concept_text: Coronary artery aneurysms are a complication of Kawasaki disease and this should be screened for with an echocardiogram

2893.concept_text: High dose aspirin is indicated in Kawasaki disease, despite it usually being contraindicated in children

2894.concept_text: High fever lasting >5 days, red palms with desquamation and strawberry tongue are indicative of Kawasaki disease

questions:
A 57-year-old man is being investigated for anaemia by his general practitioner. He has been experiencing mild shortness of breath for 2 months now. His past medical history is significant for polymyalgia rheumatica.

His latest blood tests come back as follows:

Hb99 g/LMale: (135 - 180)
Female: (115 - 160)
MCV74 fl(76 - 95 fl)
Ferritin190 ng/mL(20 - 230)
Total Iron Binding Capacity600 µg/dL(250 - 450)

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
This man presents a complex picture of anaemia, which has numerous possible sources. His anaemia is microcytic/normocytic and is alongside normal ferritin and raised TIBC. However, this is complicated by his polymyalgia rheumatica. This is an inflammatory disorder, and inflammation will raise ferritin concentration, meaning this may not be a reliable measurement to look at. Ferritin is an acute-phase reactant and is therefore raised in inflammation.

Iron deficient anaemia classically comes as microcytic, with a high total iron-binding capacity. The high TIBC is because the body still has the capability to transport iron around the body since there is not a high concentration of iron currently. Iron deficient anaemia will also have low ferritin, but this man's ferritin levels may not be representative due to his chronic inflammatory condition. Therefore, due to the high TIBC, iron-deficient anaemia is the most likely diagnosis.

Anaemia of chronic disease will also be normocytic, but will likely have a low or normal TIBC. This is because, in anaemia of chronic disease, there is not a lack of iron, but the iron is trapped elsewhere and not able to be used. For example, it is trapped in inflammatory tissue. However, since it is therefore still in the body, the capability of the body to attach to free iron and transport it around is reduced (or normal), represented by TIBC.

B12 deficiency would result in a macrocytic anaemia, and therefore this cannot be the correct answer.

Haemolytic anaemia would result in a normocytic anaemia. It is a comparably rare form of anaemia, and would not explain the abnormalities in iron studies that are seen.

Thalassemia can be considered in a microcytic anaemia. It is normally only considered after iron deficiency has been ruled out. In this case, iron deficiency is a more likely diagnosis due to the results of the iron studies.

His latest blood tests come back as follows:

Hb99 g/LMale: (135 - 180)
Female: (115 - 160)
MCV74 fl(76 - 95 fl)
Ferritin190 ng/mL(20 - 230)
Total Iron Binding Capacity600 µg/dL(250 - 450)

What is the most likely diagnosis?
question_notes:
This man presents a complex picture of anaemia, which has numerous possible sources. His anaemia is microcytic/normocytic and is alongside normal ferritin and raised TIBC. However, this is complicated by his polymyalgia rheumatica. This is an inflammatory disorder, and inflammation will raise ferritin concentration, meaning this may not be a reliable measurement to look at. Ferritin is an acute-phase reactant and is therefore raised in inflammation.

Iron deficient anaemia classically comes as microcytic, with a high total iron-binding capacity. The high TIBC is because the body still has the capability to transport iron around the body since there is not a high concentration of iron currently. Iron deficient anaemia will also have low ferritin, but this man's ferritin levels may not be representative due to his chronic inflammatory condition. Therefore, due to the high TIBC, iron-deficient anaemia is the most likely diagnosis.

Anaemia of chronic disease will also be normocytic, but will likely have a low or normal TIBC. This is because, in anaemia of chronic disease, there is not a lack of iron, but the iron is trapped elsewhere and not able to be used. For example, it is trapped in inflammatory tissue. However, since it is therefore still in the body, the capability of the body to attach to free iron and transport it around is reduced (or normal), represented by TIBC.

B12 deficiency would result in a macrocytic anaemia, and therefore this cannot be the correct answer.

Haemolytic anaemia would result in a normocytic anaemia. It is a comparably rare form of anaemia, and would not explain the abnormalities in iron studies that are seen.

Thalassemia can be considered in a microcytic anaemia. It is normally only considered after iron deficiency has been ruled out. In this case, iron deficiency is a more likely diagnosis due to the results of the iron studies.
title: Iron studies
body:
Serum iron

Total iron binding capacity (TIBC)
  • transferrin
  • raised in iron deficiency anaemia (IDA)
  • raised in pregnancy and by oestrogen

Transferrin saturation
  • calculated by serum iron / TIBC

Ferritin
  • raised in inflammatory disorders
  • low in IDA

Rarer tests
  • transferrin receptors increased in IDA

Anaemia of chronic disease
  • normochromic/hypochromic, normocytic anaemia
  • reduced serum and TIBC
  • normal or raised ferritin
concept: Iron defiency anaemia vs. anaemia of chronic disease: TIBC is high in IDA, and low/normal in anaemia of chronic disease

2275.concept_text: Iron defiency anaemia vs. anaemia of chronic disease: TIBC is high in IDA, and low/normal in anaemia of chronic disease

options: Continue with her current dietary regimen
questions:
A 35-year-old woman with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis attends a meeting with her clinical team to review her progress. It is noted that she has been losing weight and is more tired than usual. She reports having difficulty chewing and swallowing food, even if it has been mashed or pureed.

What long-term management option is best for this patient?
notes:
The correct answer is to insert a percutaneous gastronomy (PEG) tube. Patients with motor neurone disease (MND) may eventually require nutritional support if they struggle to feed themselves. An individual may initially benefit from having smaller meals and taking longer to eat them, and then making the consistency of the food more liquid-like, but this patient is struggling even with softer food. Therefore, a definitive long-term management option for this patient would be a PEG tube.

The other options are incorrect:

Continuing with her current diet regimen is incorrect as the patient is struggling with chewing and swallowing even soft food and is suffering from poor nutrition. There is a risk that she may aspirate alongside the risk of losing further weight, and so a change must be made.

Initiating total parenteral nutrition is incorrect as this is very much a last-resort measure used when there is poor functioning of the digestive tract, such as impaired nutrient absorption.

Inserting a nasogastric tube is incorrect, as although it is an appropriate way to deliver nutrition, it must be removed after 4-6 weeks to avoid adverse effects such as ulceration.

Inserting a percutaneous jejunostomy tube is incorrect. Although a jejunostomy tube is very similar to a gastrostomy tube (except for its placement site), it is much less commonly used and is harder to maintain than a PEG tube.

A 35-year-old woman with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis attends a meeting with her clinical team to review her progress. It is noted that she has been losing weight and is more tired than usual. She reports having difficulty chewing and swallowing food, even if it has been mashed or pureed.

What long-term management option is best for this patient?

An individual may initially benefit from having smaller meals and taking longer to eat them, and then making the consistency of the food more liquid-like, but this patient is struggling even with softer food. title: Motor neuron disease: management
body:
Motor neuron disease is a neurological condition of unknown cause which can present with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. It rarely presents before 40 years and various patterns of disease are recognised including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, progressive muscular atrophy and bulbar palsy

Riluzole
  • prevents stimulation of glutamate receptors
  • used mainly in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • prolongs life by about 3 months

Respiratory care
  • non-invasive ventilation (usually BIPAP) is used at night
  • studies have shown a survival benefit of around 7 months

Nutrition
  • percutaneous gastrostomy tube (PEG) is the preferred way to support nutrition and has been associated with prolonged survival

Prognosis
  • poor: 50% of patients die within 3 years
concept: Percutaneous gastrostomy tube (PEG) is the preferred way to support nutrition in patents with motor neuron disease
links:
NICE77
2016 Motor neurone disease: assessment and management
media:
Motor neuron disease
Zero To Finals - YouTube20

11795.concept_text: Percutaneous gastrostomy tube (PEG) is the preferred way to support nutrition in patents with motor neuron disease

questions: You are a foundation doctor working on the neonatal ward. You perform a newborn examination on a seven hour old baby. The baby was born at 37 weeks by normal vaginal delivery. There are no risk factors for sepsis, no maternal concerns and the baby was born in good condition. On the exam you note good tone but the peripheries are blue with cyanosis. The rest of the examination is normal. Oxygen saturations are 97% pre and post ductally. What is the likely diagnosis?
notes:
The correct answer is Acrocyanosis, which is a completely normal finding in newborn babies within the first 24-48 hours of life. It is characterised by peripheral cyanosis (bluish discolouration of the hands and feet) with normal central perfusion and normal oxygen saturations. This physiological phenomenon occurs due to peripheral vasoconstriction and the normal transition from fetal to newborn circulation. The presence of good tone, normal oxygen saturations both pre and post-ductally, and absence of other concerning features supports this diagnosis.

Hypothermia is incorrect because although it can cause peripheral vasoconstriction and bluish discolouration, a hypothermic baby would typically show other signs such as poor feeding, lethargy, and cold trunk on palpation. The stem mentions good tone which goes against this diagnosis.

Cardiac disease is incorrect because significant cardiac disease causing cyanosis would typically present with central cyanosis and/or a difference between pre and post-ductal saturations (depending on the lesion). The normal pre and post-ductal saturations of 97% effectively rule out cyanotic heart disease.

Sepsis is incorrect because there are no risk factors mentioned, and a septic neonate would typically present with other features such as respiratory distress, temperature instability, poor feeding, or lethargy. The stem specifically mentions no risk factors for sepsis and good condition at birth.

Pulmonary hypertension is incorrect because persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) typically presents with central cyanosis, respiratory distress, and importantly, a significant difference between pre and post-ductal saturations (>5%). The normal pre and post-ductal saturations rule out this diagnosis.

The rest of the examination is normal. Oxygen saturations are 97% pre and post ductally. What is the likely diagnosis?

The presence of good tone, normal oxygen saturations both pre and post-ductally, and absence of other concerning features supports this diagnosis.

The normal pre and post-ductal saturations of 97% effectively rule out cyanotic heart disease.

The normal pre and post-ductal saturations rule out this diagnosis.
title: Cyanosis in the neonatal period
body:
Peripheral cyanosis, for example of the feet and hands, is very common in the first 24 hours of life and may occur when the child is crying or unwell from any cause

Central cyanosis can be recognised clinically when the concentration of reduced haemoglobin in the blood exceeds 5g/dl

The nitrogen washout test (also known as the hyperoxia test) may be used to differentiate cardiac from non-cardiac causes. The infant is given 100% oxygen for ten minutes after which arterial blood gases are taken. A pO2 of less than 15 kPa indicates cyanotic congenital heart disease

Causes of cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
  • transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  • tricuspid atresia

Initial management of suspected cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • supportive care
  • prostaglandin E1 e.g. alprostadil
    • used to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus in ductal-dependent congenital heart defect
    • this can act as a holding measure until a definite diagnosis is made and surgical correction performed

Acrocyanosis

Acrocyanosis is often seen in healthy newborns and refers to cyanosis around the mouth and the extremities such as the hands and feet. It is differentiated from other causes of peripheral cyanosis with significant pathology as it occurs immediately after birth in healthy infants. It is a common finding and may persist for 24 to 48 hours.
concept: Acrocyanosis (peripheral cyanosis around the mouth and extremities) is common in neonates

3499.concept_text: Acrocyanosis (peripheral cyanosis around the mouth and extremities) is common in neonates
